head.title: Palestinians Raid Israel in Attempt to Capture Soldier

hedline.hl1: Palestinians Raid Israel in Attempt to Capture Soldier
hedline.hl2: Palestinians Attempt to Capture Israeli Soldier

abstract.p: At least four Palestinian gunmen break through Israel's border fence from Gaza and fight gun battle with Israel soldiers, while Israeli troops enter Gaza near Rafah to search for weapons and tunnels used to smuggle arms and explosives from Egypt; photo (M)

block.p: At least four Palestinian gunmen using an armored vehicle and grenade launchers broke through Israel's border fence from Gaza on Saturday and fought a gun battle with Israeli soldiers, while Israeli troops entered Gaza near the southern town of Rafah to search for weapons and tunnels used to smuggle arms and explosives from Egypt.

One of the Palestinian gunmen was shot dead after the armored vehicle, labeled ''TV,'' crashed through the border fence at the old Kissufim crossing, near Deir el Balah, according to the Israeli Army. A spokesman for Islamic Jihad, Abu Ahmed, said three of the four gunmen had returned to Gaza, and the intention had been to try to capture an Israeli soldier.
The battle lasted two to three hours, but no Israeli was wounded or captured, the Israeli Army said.

At least four Palestinian gunmen using an armored vehicle and grenade launchers broke through Israel's border fence from Gaza on Saturday and fought a gun battle with Israeli soldiers, while Israeli troops entered Gaza near the southern town of Rafah to search for weapons and tunnels used to smuggle arms and explosives from Egypt.

One of the Palestinian gunmen was shot dead after the armored vehicle, labeled ''TV,'' crashed through the border fence at the old Kissufim crossing, near Deir el Balah, according to the Israeli Army. A spokesman for Islamic Jihad, Abu Ahmed, said three of the four gunmen had returned to Gaza, and the intention had been to try to capture an Israeli soldier.
The battle lasted two to three hours, but no Israeli was wounded or captured, the Israeli Army said.

The attack evoked the Hamas raid into Israel a year ago, in which several Israeli soldiers were killed and another, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, was captured. He is still being held somewhere in Gaza. Negotiations for a prisoner exchange have been intermittent but have faltered over Hamas demands for prisoners Israel does not want to release.

Abu Ahmed told Gaza radio stations that four militants had broken through the Gaza border fence. ''It is difficult to storm,'' he said. ''But when they entered in a surprise, they confused the enemy.''
He said the raid had been carried out with the help of members of the Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, affiliated with Fatah.
The intention, he said afterward, was to kidnap an Israeli soldier but the mission failed.

An Israeli Army spokesman confirmed that ''four or five gunmen infiltrated through the border fence into Israel.'' They approached an Israeli Army post and there was a gun battle in which the Israelis confirmed shooting one man and killing him.

Abu Ali, a spokesman for the Al Aksa brigades, said the gunmen used an armored jeep with United Nations markings to ram the border post. The Israeli Army, which has the jeep, said it was marked ''TV,'' the standard way that the news media signify their vehicles.

Islamic Jihad, a small radical military group supported largely by Iran, has always rejected any sort of cease-fire with Israel and carried out all four successful suicide bombing attacks in Israel in 2006.

Earlier on Saturday, Israeli tanks and troops made another incursion into the southern Gaza Strip, engaging members of the military wing of Hamas and killing at least one of them, according to the army, Hamas and Israel Radio.

The Israeli troops moved at least a mile into Gaza just east of the city of Rafah. The troops called on male residents over the age of 16 to surrender for questioning, according to the Palestinian National Security Forces, one of the Palestinian police groups.

An Israeli Army spokesman said that about 50 Palestinians had been detained for questioning, but only those with ''connections to terrorist organizations'' would be held for more intensive questioning. The operation was continuing Saturday night.

The Israelis said their troops had come under fire from Hamas and had shot back, hitting an armed man. The troops are searching for weapons stores and tunnels used to smuggle weapons, ammunition and explosives into Gaza from nearby Egypt, the Israelis said.

Israeli troops made a similar incursion near Rafah on Monday, in a daylong operation in which they took in 40 Palestinians for questioning and released all but four men, the Israeli Army spokesman said. The four were arrested and brought back to Israel for further questioning.

The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, told leaders of his Fatah movement that a collapse of the unity government with Hamas would lead to further chaos. ''The alternative to the national unity government is chaos and loss,'' he said, according to the Palestinian daily newspaper Al Ayyam. He promised that ''Fatah will not be the trigger to ignite the fire, but it will work to extinguish the fire.''
